lines.text:
[to John]
You're a very courageous man. I mean, taking upon yourself the responsibility for altering the course of another person's life.

[Judge Chapman has realized who David really is]
You know, don't you?

I know I'd seen you before... but I couldn't quite remember. Each time... each time I had a stroke, it was you waiting. Every time I thought the pain was so bad that it was all over, you were there, weren't you? Standing off a way.
[he chuckles]
Waiting... but you were always so dim, so... so vague.
I think you're a phony... a very clever gold-digging phony, Mr. Smith. I intend to prove that to Peggy and to Judge Chapman.
You'd be well advised to leave well enough alone.
But thing's aren't well enough, are they? There's something wrong about you. I want you out of here, off this island.
I'm afraid your wants are the least of my concerns right now.
I'll tell you something, Smith... if I have to beat the truth out of you, I'll do it!
Take my advice, Mr. Cummings... don't get involved in matters far beyond your control... and far beyond your possible understanding.

[Judge Chapman has realized who David really is]
You know, don't you?

I knew I'd seen you before... but I couldn't quite remember. Each time... each time I had a stroke, it was you waiting. Every time I thought the pain was so bad that it was all over, you were there, weren't you? Standing off a way.
[he chuckles]
Waiting... but you were always so dim, so... so vague.
Giving up is not something I do easily.

I came here to solve what for me has been a riddle for as long as there's been life. I had to understand why people cling so tenaciously to living... why they're so afraid of what I can bring them. I want to know what is there that makes men and women fight so desperately to remain in a world so unhappy, so filled with hate and now so polluted with real poisons.

[to his wife]
Your daughter may walk out of here on Death's arm and you just sit there saying "Let's wish her well!"
For you, Death has been the enemy, the destroyer, the arch-villain.
He's your friend, I suppose? After all that you've... that this family has suffered?

No... he's not my friend. But if I couldn't accept his existence by now, my mind would have been in pieces years ago. No, to me he's just a fact like night or clouds or quiet. How could there be anything so terrifying about anything so common, so inevitable? I don't mean that we should just lie back and accept death like another rainy day, but when it comes to that last moment, who's to say that it's a tragedy... except for those of us who may survive? But no one can speak for those who have left us.
Peggy's hardly even been here yet! In the day of her life, this is only mid-morning!
There is a tragedy in dying... in dying not knowing absolute love.

[Peggy has tried to throw herself off the cliff]
Peggy! What were you trying to do?
You know what I was trying to do.
Why? Why would you want to?

[she touches his face]
I thought you'd look different... but you don't.
He told you?
Yes.
And now?
I don't know... I was so frightened at first, so many things bouncing around in my head and then... absolute stillness inside. There were no more questions I had to ask.
But you still haven't told me why! Why this?
Because I wanted to leave with you.
[last lines]
Peggy, if I don't stay I'll have to take you, and I can't! I love you, Peggy! I can't take all those years of living from you, not when you make them count for so much!
David, I've waited for you all my life! Do you know what I'm saying? All my life!
[They embrace]
If I go with you, can we be together as we are right now?
Yes.
For ever?
More.
Then I want to go with you. Now.
Peggy, I can't promise you that it will be either more or less than you may have imagined.
I know.
You won't regret it?
No... not with you.
But you're so young! You've had so few years.
Most people live 'til they're eighty and never know the fulfillment I've known. David... it's Christmas morning. I want to open the next package.

[first lines, waking up on the beach after nearly drowning]
I don't remember... the last thing I know I was in a big kelp bed. I remember thinking I'd never come up from down there. But here I am, aren't I... I guess.
You do take too many chances.
Now how many is too many? I mean, you don't know until you take the last one, do you? And then that could be the first time or the hundredth

[Peggy has asked him to tell her about himself]
In my earliest recollected incarnation, I was the poet Euripedes. That was about 480 B.C. My next trip in was as John the Baptist.
[Peggy laughs]
Not too happy a choice, as it turned out. And then somewhere around 810 I served a hitch in Charlemagne's army. Yes, I was a general, I think... at least I had a very fancy uniform.
Wonderful! Because at this rate, we'll be here all night.
Wait 'til I get to the fifteenth century. That was easily my best century.
45 on Friday... when all death stopped everywhere! When Peggy-...
Drowned. When Peggy accidentally drowned.

[grabs hold of David's arm]
No! Not Peggy! Please!
45 Friday her body washed up on the beach.
But you let her live!
I extended her time a little.

[pause, then]
How long?
Tomorrow. When the weekend is over, I'll take her with me.

What happens in some other life doesn't interest me... why we were put here in the first place doesn't interest me. We're here and every second of it has meaning, and to throw away even one little second is wrong.
Was falling in love with my daughter part of your study?

[long pause, then]
No... that wasn't planned.

[to Judge Chapman]
You won't believe me, will you? I'm not a judge, I'm not God, I'm not even an executioner.
